text: Awesome, I've sent it around to a few course mates as well to see if they could spot anything, the more feedback the better :smile:

Hey Josh! Sorry for the delay. I was skimming through this article over the past few days to see if it would be of any use to you. <https://www.ukscreenalliance.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/The_Core_Skills_of_VFX_-_Student_Primer.pdf>
I don't know if you've seen it already but from what I read so far I 100% support all of the points brought up in that primer.
I'm also taking a look at your syncsketch at the moment. Didn't you have some slowmo ref in there as well of a dog running?

For the run-up on the boardwalk, I'd suggest doing some reading on the different gaits of a horse. Most quadrupeds share the same gaits and gait mechanics, and there's a lot of information out there detailing how horse gaits work.

They won't be exactly the same for a dog, but there's a lot of similarities that might help. Quadrupeds essentially have 4 speeds or gears, each one with its own footfall pattern, and one thing I noticed about the run is that currently, I can't quite tell which gait it's in.

Some of your posing looks like you're trying to go into 4th gear, where there's a moment of suspension and no feet are touching the ground, but your footfalls are following a 3rd gear (canter) pattern where at least one foot is touching the ground at any given time.
It was MeeTeck that linked the slowmo dog run. Stunning ref and a good display of the 4th gear run with some footfall air suspension. :smile:

That being said, from what I'm seeing in your ref most look to be in 3rd gear. You have a bunch of reference (which is great), but for your shot I'd suggest picking one that's good and sticking to it as being your driver for what you do with your animation, meaning you'll use it to animate your shot to and ignore everything else to a degree. Your other ref will be good for understanding mechanics and getting different angles on what's happening, but you've got 2 shots that are pretty similar in camera angle, so might as well use those to nail the action. :smiley:

I had a read over the rest of MeeTeck's feedback and I agree with a lot of their points. The main point I was gonna give was one they mentioned as well, which is key poses.
Figure out what type of run you're doing, figure out the footfalls, the hip and chest up/downs, hip + chest rotations, and make sure you *nail* those poses. If you can get those key poses right your animation will go a long way without needing further adjustments.

This is true for the run but it applies to any animation, really. You'll need breakdowns and polish obviously to get it looking really accurate and pretty, but if you can ace the key poses the majority of the work will be done where people will have no question about whether or not what they're looking at works or not.
Very excited to see where this goes, dude!
Awesome, thank you for the feedback :smile: I've noted everything down and I'll be addressing it all this I'll send you the next iteration towards the end of the week :slightly_smiling_face:
Also huge thanks for the article I've given it a skim and it looks super helpful, I'll be sharing it with my course mates :smile:
